title: 115_hr5735
content: The "Transitional Housing for Recovery in Viable Environments Demonstration Program Act" or the "THRIVE Act" establishes a program to study the impact of using rental vouchers for supportive housing for individuals recovering from opioid use disorders or other substance use disorders. Section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to establish a rental voucher demonstration program for supportive housing for individuals recovering from opioid use disorders or other substance use disorders. The program allocates funds for eligible entities to provide vouchers for housing assistance through supportive housing programs that offer treatment for substance use disorders. The rental voucher demonstration program under Section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 provides vouchers for housing assistance to individuals recovering from opioid use disorders or other substance use disorders. Eligible entities offer treatment for substance use disorders, workforce development coordination, and determined assistance. The amount allocated for fiscal year 2019 is based on a percentage of vouchers renewed or a maximum of 10,000 vouchers. The curr_chunk describes the requirements for entities to provide evidence-based treatment programs and coordinate with workforce development providers for individuals recovering from substance use disorders. They must also have experience administering rental assistance vouchers or supportive housing programs. The curr_chunk outlines the application requirements for eligible entities to receive rental assistance vouchers, including descriptions of treatment programs, coordination with workforce development providers, and rental assistance for individuals in need. The curr_chunk details the requirements for eligible entities to provide transitional plans for covered individuals completing treatment programs, including information on additional treatment, workforce development opportunities, and housing resources. The curr_chunk outlines the selection criteria for eligible entities to receive rental assistance vouchers under the demonstration program, ensuring diversity and a balance between urban and rural areas. The selection criteria for eligible entities to receive rental assistance vouchers under the demonstration program include having adequate resources for treatment, complying with housing and civil rights laws, reflecting the impact of opioids in tribal communities, and providing supportive housing in regions with high opioid mortality rates. The selection criteria for eligible entities to receive rental assistance vouchers under the demonstration program include considering mortality rates due to opioid use disorders, success in helping individuals complete treatment programs, and coordination with health and labor departments. The eligible entities receiving rental assistance vouchers must coordinate with workforce development providers, track participants in unsubsidized employment post-program exit, and monitor the success rate of participants in treatment programs to prevent relapse into substance usage. Upon program completion, vouchers may be reissued. The provision allows for rental assistance vouchers to be transferred from one covered individual to another. The rental assistance period is limited to 5 years from the enactment date. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify requirements for voucher use, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards. The Secretary has the authority to waive or modify requirements for voucher use, excluding fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards. An eligible entity receiving a rental assistance voucher must submit an annual transitional plan and housing information for covered individuals. The Secretary can waive or modify voucher requirements, except for fair housing and nondiscrimination laws. Eligible entities must provide a transitional plan and housing details for covered individuals. Additionally, a report analyzing treatment and housing options for voucher recipients must be submitted to Congress within 4 years of enactment. The report analyzing the impact of rental assistance provided under this paragraph must be submitted to Congress within 2 and 4 years of enactment. The term 'eligible entity' refers to a tribally designated housing entity as defined in the Native American Housing and Self-Determination Act of 1996. The term 'covered individual' refers to an individual recovering from an opioid use disorder or other substance use disorder. SEC. 3. REPEAL OF RENTAL VOUCHER DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. Paragraph (21) of section 8(o) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 will be repealed 5 years after this Act's enactment. SEC. 4. DEMONSTRATION CLOSE-OUT. Entities providing rental assistance vouchers must return them to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development within 5 years for renewal of expiring contracts. SEC. 5. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. SEC. 5. NO ADDITIONAL FUNDS AUTHORIZED. No additional funds are authorized for this Act's requirements and amendments. Funding will come from existing appropriations.
